title: Airbnb-style childcare service Koru Kids could be the solution for London's working parents
text:
Airbnb-style childcare service Koru Kids could be the solution for London's working parents 
The nanny network has 1,000 families on the network from word of mouth alone Thursday 26 January 2017 10:10 BST Click to followES Lifestyle The kids are alright Getty Images/Hero Images 
Rachel Carrell is reeling off the stories that encouraged her to launch her nanny-sharing website, Koru Kids . “I have friends who say they want another baby but feel they can’t afford to because of the cost of childcare ,” she tells me. “Others who want to go back to work just can’t make it pay. These aren’t minor, incidental problems but profound ones that shape lives.” 
This affects more than just parents. Another couple she knows are both surgeons. Their son goes to nursery and if he is ever ill — “even just a loose stool” — they have to leave the hospital and pick him up. He then isn’t allowed back in for 48 hours. “That means they have to cancel surgeries.” 
A childcare crisis is brewing in the capital. As Tulip Siddiq MP, shadow minister for the early years, notes: “London suffers from a double whammy when it comes to childcare: high costs and a lack of childcare places for parents to access.” The number of childminders is falling, while nurseries are being squeezed by rising rents and staff costs. 
Carrell believes Koru Kids, based in Euston, can be part of the solution. Even before the formal launch, Carrell already has more than 1,000 families on the network from word of mouth: both parents who already have their nannies but are looking to reduce the cost, and parents hoping this could help them afford higher-quality childcare. 'Help parents pay upfront fees for childcare', Khan tells employers 
The site launches publicly today, after fundraising closed last week. The co-founder of Gumtree, Michael Pennington — whom Carrell had not met before — was among the investors who gave her £600,000 in seed funding. Pennington says: “Through Gumtree I’m very aware how parents struggle to find quality childcare and nannies. Koru Kids [allows] parents to socialise their children with other children from like-minded families, and at the same time reduces the cost of having a nanny.” 
According to the firm’s research, nanny-sharing could create 30,000 extra childcare places in London. 
A survey of more than 600 Mary Poppinses and Mrs Doubtfires showed that 17 per cent are currently in a nanny share, with a further 40 per cent saying they would like to be part of one if a job became available. Rachel Carrell is already inundated with nannies and parents who want to use her new childcare sharing website 
Carrell, 36, was formerly the chief executive of DrThom, the largest online doctors’ service, and then ran a chain of IVF clinics. While at DrThom, she had her daughter Naomi, now two, who shared a child-minder with another baby. This gave Carrell her eureka moment for Koru. “Talking to other parents, one of the things that kept coming up was that they wanted to do a nanny share but couldn’t find the right family to pair up with.” 
Carrell started an early test-run in 2016, to see if parents would sign up. “I hoped I could get one family interested but I got 37 straight away.” She quit her job that day. A range of helpful features allows you to see, hear and communicate with your tot with ease. A built in sensor measures room temperature and humidity. It also includes a soothing nightlight, a selection of lullabies and a reassuring talk back function – all of which can be controlled by the user-friendly app. You are also able to share a secure and private video stream with up to ten other family members – so grandma can check in too. Its large 4.3 inch colour LCD screen has a handy pan, tilt and zoom camera that spans a large area – a useful feature for parents who have more than one child sleeping in a room. It also comes with an in-built temperature sensor and the talk back function that allows you to soothe your little one from anywhere in the house. £109, Amazon, Buy it now 4/6 Motorola Smart Nursery 7

A specialised app called Hubble lets you view the camera on compatible smartphones and tablets – you can also receive sound, motion, humidity and temperature alerts, along with HD video streaming. Other useful features include sleep quality monitoring - a clever feature that tracks your baby’s snooze habits. The large 3.5 inch portable, colour screen offers quality video transmission and crystal clear sound quality. It also comes with an innovative sensor pad that is designed to be placed under-the-mattress to detect movement. This is a great feature for newborns or tots who have just started to reach and stand. It’s super easy to set up and has an intelligent talk-back feature so you can settle baby without going into their room, plus a choice of two soothing lullabies. It also includes a temperature sensor and belt clip. £24.99, Aldi, Buy it now 
Parents supply details — their postcodes and “nanny needs” (for example, French-speaking). Koru searches the database and then presents users with the best one or two matches. “We made a conscious decision that this would be a matching service rather than a listing,” Carrell explains. “Parents kept saying they didn’t want yet another website they had to trawl through — that was the word that kept coming up, ‘trawl’. This is much more time-efficient for them.” 
Parents can then meet the best matches and the nanny. Koru also helps with that process too. “When you take on a nanny, you legally have to be the employer. We take care of payroll and all that. It’s an entire service. Because if you put yourself in the mind of someone going back to work after maternity leave, you’re thinking ‘Do my clothes still fit?’, ‘Will I still be able to do my job?’ Do you really want to be researching payroll companies too?” 
Koru charges management and commission fees but Carrell says it is still “roughly a third cheaper” than hiring a nanny. They earn more too: “Doing a nanny share is the best way nannies can improve their hourly rate, so it gives career progression.” That’s the spoonful of sugar that makes the nanny-share go down.
